_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is submitted to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to meet the requirements of Section 112? of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, codified in the Code of Federal Regulation Title 40 Part 68.

Stationary Source and Chemical of Concern
The Silver Bay Seafoods Craig facility is located in Craig, Alaska.  The facility produces fresh and frozen seafood products, using anhydrous ammonia in a closed system as a refrigerant.  Ammonia is the safest refrigerant available and has excellent warning properties; it is extremely pungent at levels far below dangerous concentrations.  In calculating worst-case and alternative scenarios, efforts were made in all cases to overestimate rather than underestimate the effects of a release.  The facility system is new; it was installed in 2009.

Worst-Case Scenario
A worst case scenario is required to be documented in the RMP.  Based on the requirements of the RMP rule, it is assumed that the catastrophic failure of the largest vessel in the system results in the release of its entire contents over a 10-minute period.  The release is modeled using RMP*Comp? software. 

Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario for the ammonia refrigeration process is based on a potential hazard identified during the Process Hazard Analysis conducted during documentation of the facility?s prevention plan.  In this scenario, some tubing is cracked, releasing ammonia gas to the atmosphere.  No mitigation is considered in the scenario calculations as the release occurs outdoors.  The release is evaluated according to the procedures documented in ?General Risk Management Program Guidance? (April 2004), Appendix E ?Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration Facilities? and with RMP*Comp? software.

Release Prevention Program 
Silver Bay Seafoods has implemented a prevention program to comply with the requirements of the Process Safety Management (PSM) standar

d (29 CFR 1910.119), which is designed to prevent accidental releases of all chemicals held in quantities over given thresholds.  The PSM program addresses all required elements including employee participation, process safety information, operating procedures, hot work permits, management of change, mechanical integrity, training, pre-startup review, compliance audits, process hazard analysis, contractor safety, incident investigation and emergency planning.  The system has many safety features built in including high and low level controls and alarms, high pressure shut downs, pressure relief valves, automatic and manually controlled valves, check valves, and programmable logic control capabilities.

Five Year Accident History
Per the requirements of 40 CFR 68.42, facilities must include a five-year accident history for all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  There has been no such incident at the facility.

Emergency Response
The Silver Bay Seafoods Craig facility maintains a written emergency action plan to facilitate a safe resolution to any emergency ammonia release.  The plan identifies personnel designated and trained to assist in evacuation, make required notifications, and conduct the necessary actions to help ensure employee and community safety during an emergency.  The facility has coordinated its emergency action plan with local responders and will conduct drills periodically to practice required actions.
